A Multi-Period Analysis ABSTRACT For many years, the post-earnings announcement drift (PEAD) has been accepted as an anomaly to the efficient markets hypothesis. This drift subsequent to earnings announcements has been ascribed to the incomplete incorporation by the market of the information in these earnings announcements. Interestingly, over the past five decades of extensive research, no rational economic explanation of the PEAD has been found. However, there has been no specific consideration of the effect of economic information subsequent to the earnings announcements. Our multi-year examination of the cumulative abnormal return (CAR) incorporates the effect of economic information subsequent to the earnings announcement of traditional PEAD studies. Our analysis shows that a PEAD can arise without recourse to invoking market inefficiency. Our results are consistent for three samples covering the period 1973 to 2016. We do not assert that we prove that there is no component of the PEAD due to market inefficiency. Rather, our results show that studies to determine whether there is a market inefficiency component of the PEAD should use a multi-period approach in order to account for the effect of economic information subsequent to the earnings announcements and thereby focus more precisely upon the cause of the PEAD reported in previous research studies. text: The Post-Earnings Announcement Drift – A Pre-Earnings Announcement Effect? A Multi-Period Analysis I. INTRODUCTION The post-earnings announcement drift (PEAD), first reported in the seminal paper of Ball and Brown (1968), was labelled as an efficient market anomaly and is still so characterized some 50 years later. PEAD is defined as a drift in the plot of the cumulative abnormal return versus time for a period of months subsequent to the announcement of accounting earnings. More specifically, past studies have shown that cumulative abnormal return tends to drift up for good news (GN) firms (firms for which actual earnings exceed expected earnings) and down for bad news (BN) firms (firms for which expected earnings exceed actual earnings) after an earnings announcement (EA). This characterization exists in both the academic and professional literatures. In the academic literature, Ball (1992) noted: “the apparent predictability of abnormal returns after earnings announcements has become one of the most significant anomalies in financial markets research…” Fama (1998) referred to PEAD as “….the granddaddy of under-reaction events….” and stated that “the post-earnings announcement drift first reported by Ball and Brown (1968) has survived many robustness checks….” More recently, Kothari (2001) noted that “the PEAD anomaly poses a serious challenge to the efficient market hypothesis. It has survived a battery of tests and many attempts to explain it away.” In the more recent professional literature, Zhou and Zhu (2012) stated that “the post-earnings announcement drift has been one of the more robust and persistent anomalies challenging the efficient market paradigm.” 3 Electronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=3360686

text: There have been a number of potential explanations for the PEAD; yet, the anomaly continues. In this study we extend the original analysis of Ball and Brown (1968) to a multi- year context. We do not use complex models and analyses, given that their use in past studies has not changed the basic conclusion about the PEAD observed in the simpler analysis used by Ball and Brown (1968). Prior papers in the literature have a number of characteristics in common. They have accumulated data for many companies into a single sample and so averaged any effect of industry differences. They have accumulated data for many years into a single sample and so averaged the effect of changes in the economic environment over the time of the sample. They have considered only one information event, the unexpected earnings at the end of this constructed common period. They have conveyed the erroneous impression that earnings announcements convey substantial new information to the market (Smith Bamber et al. 2000; Ball and Brown 2014). In a study of serial correlation of unexpected earnings, Rendleman, Jones and Latane (1987) suggest that the PEAD has a component due to what they labelled a pre-announcement earnings effect.1 This suggestion informs our proposed approach. We assert that new economic information, i.e. economic information subsequent to the earnings announcement considered in previous studies, should be taken into account in an analysis of the PEAD. To do this, we classify the sample data into three adjacent yearlong periods rather than a single period. They inferred that a potential explanation for the non-zero slopes was market inefficiency, i.e. the incomplete recognition of the information in the EAs. Since Ball and Brown (1968), there have been many studies using data from different sources with consistent results. Foster, Olsen and Shevlin (1984) extended the Ball and Brown (1968) study in several ways (see Figure 2). First, they used quarterly EAs and daily returns in place of annual EAs and monthly returns, and more complex expectations models to calculate abnormal returns and unexpected earnings. Second, they used a more recent sample period, namely the years 1974 to 1981. Finally, given that they had a much larger sample, they classified firms into deciles based upon standardized unexpected earnings (SUE) rather than simple dichotomous good news/bad news categories. Consistent with expectations, the plots show a more positive (negative) PEAD the more positive (negative) the SUE. Their results are fundamentally consistent with those of Ball and Brown (1968). Rendleman, Jones and Latane (1987) have several studies related to SUE. For a 1971 Q3 to 1980 Q4 sample, they show that SUEs are correlated over time, which led them to the conclusion that “what may appear as a post-announcement response to current quarter earnings may actually be a pre-announcement adjustment to next quarter’s earnings.” More specifically, these authors suggest that only approximately half of the observed PEAD is a “real” PEAD in the proper sense of the word and is consistent with serial correlation in SUEs. They posit that the remaining 50% is likely a pre-announcement adjustment to next quarter’s earnings. text: Bernard and Thomas (1989, 1990) used the same basic approach as Foster, Olsen and Shevlin (1984), extending the sample to the period 1974 to 1986. They investigated possible explanations for the PEAD and found results that are consistent with a delayed price response. In other words, given that a firm announces positive (negative) unexpected earnings for quarter t, the market tends to be positively (negatively) surprised in the days surrounding the announcement for quarter t+1. They concluded that the results imply that investors on average do not understand the implications of current quarterly earnings for future earnings and instead rely on a simple random walk model with a drift to form earnings expectations. They found no evidence to support the hypothesis that the effects are due to problems with risk adjustment or the impact of transaction costs. However, they did not consider any effect of economic information subsequent to the earnings announcement. Nichols and Wahlen (2004) replicated the Ball and Brown (1968) and Bernard and Thomas (1989, 1990) studies, using a sample for the years 1988 to 2002, and obtained consistent results. A significant amount of research from the 1990s and early 2000s posits that the drift is affected by the extent to which sophisticated investors can limit the mispricing, consistent with a transaction cost explanation for at least part of the persistence of the drift. This “limit to arbitrage” explanation suggests that the largest mispricing occurs in those stocks which are costly to arbitrage. This means that when transaction costs are low, we might see little mispricing because any mispricing is quickly arbitraged away. In contrast, when the transaction costs are high, arbitrageurs abstain from trading until the mispricing becomes large enough to make a profit. text: In summary, there is an extensive PEAD literature, with multiple interpretations which include: (1) investors’ under-reaction to earnings surprises; (2) transaction costs; (3) information uncertainty; and (4) investor sentiment. Interestingly, however, the anomaly remains. In the sections that follow, our objective is to show the reader that if one is to properly test for market inefficiency, the influence of subsequent economic news in a multi-year context should be taken into account. 2.2 Hypothesis Development Previous studies of the PEAD have considered a single earnings announcement (EA – annual/quarterly) and examined the behavior of the cumulative abnormal return (CAR) versus time (months/days) for periods before and after the EA. Typically, the number of months/trading days is 12/60 before and up to 12/60 after for annual/quarterly EAs3. For annual EAs, CAR is calculated for each of the 12 months in the year preceding the EAs at year end and the months after the EAs. These calculations are done independently of the subsequent classification of firms as good news (GN) or bad news (BN) based on the sign of the unexpected earnings (UE) calculated at the time of the annual earnings release. Average CARs for each month are then calculated for the firms in each of the GN and BN classifications and used to prepare a plot of CAR versus months from 12 months before the EAs to typically 6 months after the EAs. The finding of positive/negative slopes for a plot of CAR versus month during the 12 months before the EA for GN/BN firms can be explained, at least in part, as the effect of economic information during the year, which affects the market price of the shares of the firm. This economic information also affects the operational results of the firm, which are reflected in the end of year accounting earnings, and so the UE used to classify the firms as GN or BN. text: Using annual earnings data and monthly stock return data, we show that, in an analysis of CAR versus time, a multi-year approach provides new insights in the study of the PEAD. This simple extension incorporates the market reaction to new economic information (proxied by the subsequent UE, i.e. the pre-announcement effect proposed by Rendleman, Jones and Latane (1987)), in addition to reaction to old news (the UE considered in earlier studies of the PEAD). We show that a drift of a plot of CAR versus month after GN/BN UEs (PEAD) follows naturally from the slopes of the GNGN/GNBN and BNGN/BNBN plots and the relative numbers of firms in each classification after the initial UEs.
